title: Cabinet
description: Kabinet, eikenhout gefineerd met ebbenhout, marqueterie van verschillende houtsoorten, koper, tin, schildpad, hoorn en lapis lazuli. Beslag van verguld brons.

acquisition.creditLine: Purchased with the support of the Vereniging Rembrandt, with additional funding from the Prins Bernhard Fonds

documentation: R. Baarsen, 'Paar huwelijkskoffers', Bulletin van de Vereniging Rembrandt 19 (2009) nr. 2, p. 14-17.
J.N. Ronfort, 'The surviving cabinets on stands by André-Charles Boulle and the new chronology of the master's oeuvre', Cleveland Studies in the History of Art 8 (2003), p. 65.
Reinier Baarsen, 'Kabinet, toegeschreven aan Pierre Gole', Jaarverslag Vereniging Rembrandt (1990), p. 36-37.
longTitle: Cabinet, André-Charles Boulle (attributed to), c. 1670 - c. 1675
subTitle: h 189.0cm × w 129.5cm × d 62.5cm
scLabelLine: attributed to André-Charles Boulle (1642–1732), Paris, c. 1670–1675 oak, veneered with various woods, copper, pewter, tortoiseshell, horn and lapis lazuli; mounts: gilt-bronze

label.title: Cabinet
label.makerLine: attributed to André-Charles Boulle (1642–1732), Paris, c. 1670–1675 oak, veneered with various woods, copper, pewter, tortoiseshell, horn and lapis lazuli; mounts: gilt-bronze
label.description:
This may be the earliest-known masterpiece by Boulle, the most celebrated cabinetmaker of his time. Boulle perfected the technique of floral marquetry in various woods. The gilt-bronze armorial trophy above the middle door originally contained a portrait of Louis XIV. It was replaced with a likeness of King George I of
England (1660–1727).
